CHAPTER XXI

How the province of the Uplandislz English was made Christian under king Peada [653]

AT this time the Middle Englishmen‚1 that is the Uplandish English, received the saith and the myster-ies of truth under their prince Peada, the son of king Penda: who being an excellent young man, and worthy of the name and dignity of king, was of his father advanced to the govermnent of that nation3 and he came to Oswy king of the Nor-thum- bnans, requiring Alchfled his daughter to be given him to wife ε but could in no otherwise obtain his suit unless he would receive the faith of Christ and baptism, together with the nation over which he was set. Thereon, having heard the preaching of the truth, the promise of the heavenly kingdom and the hope of resurrection and immortality to come, he willingly avouched that he was ready to become a Christian, even though he should not win the maiden t being chiefly persuaded to receive the saith by king Oswy’s son, called Alehfrid, who was his brother-in- law 2 and friend, having to wife Peada’s sister, by name Cyneburg, king Penda’s daughter.

He was therefore baptized by Finan the bishop, with all the retainers and thanes who had come with him, and the whole of their servants, in a famous town of the king‘s which is called At Wall.³ And he returned home with much joy, having taken four priests who secmed fit both by learning and conduct
